step.cmd: Go to the Shanks Hall third floor break room (Room 380) and set the stove to medium/medium-low heat. Combine the cream and 2 cups of milk in a medium saucepan. Bring the mixture to a simmer.
Combine the leftover milk, sugar, cornstarch, salt, and vanilla in a small or medium mixing bowl and whisk the ingredients to mix.
Once the mixture on the stove comes to a simmer, add the ingredients you mixed in step 2 to the saucepan and stir until the ingredients are completely combined.
With the saucepan still over medium/medium-low heat, stir the mixture continuously until it begins to thicken. It should be in a strong simmer.

info.note: You will know the mixture is good enough when it coats the back of the spoon.

step.cmd: Turn the stove off and remove the pan. Now stir in the pectin. Once the pectin is mixed in, strain the mixture and let it cool to room temperature.
Place the room temperature mixture into a container and cover it. Let the mixture refridgerate for at least two hours.
After refridgerating the mixture for two hours, remove the cover and whisk the mixture.
After whisking the mixture, you may begin to use the ice cream maker. Follow the instructions on page 3 for how to turn on the appliance. For this recipe, you will be selecting the "Gelato" button.
When the machine is on and running, you may begin to pour the mixture through the spout on the lid.
Cover the spout with the cap.
Let it mix for any time between 15-40 minutes. Typically, it should take around 40 minutes, but it depends on your desired thickness for your gelato.

info.note: If the gelato is still not as thick as you'd like, transfer the gelato into an airtight container and let it freeze for 2 extra hours.
